Award.AwardTitle: WORKSHOP: Computer-Supported Cooperative Work Doctoral Colloquium

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: This workshop will support the Doctoral Colloquium (DC) at ACM Conference on Computer Supported Cooperative Work (CSCW 2011) in Hangzhou, China (March 19-23, 2011). The workshop will bring together 15 dissertation-stage doctoral students in the field of CSCW for one day of talks and interaction with six mentors who are distinguished CSCW researchers from Universities and top research laboratories. The focus of the CSCW DC is the students? doctoral dissertation research which represent state-of-the-art research in the field of computer-supported cooperative work. The DC allows the students to create a social network both among themselves and with several senior researchers, which plays a major role in their enculturation into the profession. The students and faculty will be a diverse group on several dimensions (gender, race, nationality, scientific discipline), broadening the students? experiences at a critical stage in their professional development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research consortium of promising doctoral students and research faulty was held in conjunction with the 2011 ACM Conference on Computer Supported Cooperative Work (CSCW 2011). 14 students from six countries were invited to attend the workshop. Four faculty members served as Doctoral Colloquium mentors. The students presented their work and received critique and feedback from the other students and the mentors. The feedback was geared towards helping students understand how their work was positioned with respect to the field of CSCW, whether their topics were adequately focused, whether their methods are correctly chosen, and whether their results were appropriately analyzed and presented.

The faculty critique helped direct the students on literature, methods, theory, and other topics related to their dissertation. The Colloquium provided an atmosphere where the students could comfortably present their work in a supportive environment. The Colloquium provided the faculty participants with experience in mentoring a diverse set of graduate students in an interdisciplinary field. Importantly, for an interdisciplinary field such as CSCW, the Doctoral Colloquium helps develop a cohort group of new researchers who will become a part of a global network of colleagues.  The Colloquium also served to enhance the graduate student experience at the CSCW conference and can help to ensure that a new cohort of researchers enters the field.
